columns.text: For this exercise, we need to show the change in each account from Just De It Corp during the years 2017 and 2018. Also, we need to explain whether those changes were a source or use of cash.

First, we will construct a table showing the changes on each account from 2017 to 2018.

$$\begin {array}{c}
\textbf{Just Dew It Corp}\\
\textbf{Balance Sheet Change 2017-2018 }
\end{array}$$
$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\underline{\text{Assets}}&2017&2018&\text{Change}\\
\text{Current Assets}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Cash}&\$12,157 &\$14,105 &\$1,948 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Accounts receivable }&\$29,382& \$32,815 &\$3,433 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Inventory}&\$54,632 &\$57,204 &\$2,572 \\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Total}&\underline{\$96,171} &\underline{\$104,124}&\underline{\$7,953} \\
\text{Fixed assets}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Net plant and equipment}&\underline{\$367,241}&\underline{\$375,830} &\underline{\$8,589} \\
\text{Total assets}&\underline{\underline{\$463,412 }}&\underline{\underline{\$479,954 }}&\underline{\underline{\$16,542 }}\\
\\
\underline{\text{Liabilities and Owners’ Equity}}\\
\text{Current liabilities}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Accounts payable}&\$46,382 &\$49,276 &\$2,894 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Notes payable}&\$18,246 &\$19,784 &\$1,538 \\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Total}&\underline{\$64,628} &\underline{\$69,060}&\underline{\$4,432 }\\
\text{Long-term debt}&\underline{\$49,000 }&\underline{\$45,000} &\underline{-\$4,000}\\

\text{Owners’ equity}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Common stock and paid-in surplus}&\$50,000 &\$50,000&\$0  \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Retained earnings }&\$299,784 &\$315,894 &\$16,110 \\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Total}&\underline{\underline{\$349,784}} &\underline{\underline{\$365,894}}&\underline{\underline{\$16,110}} \\

\text{Total liabilities and owners’ equity}&\underline{\underline{\$463,412 }}&{\underline{\$479,954  }}&{\underline{\$16,542 }}\\

\end{array}$$

Now we can construct a table showing whether these changes account for a use of cash or a source of cash. 

Remember that an increase in assets and ad decrease of liabilities are considered the **use** of cash. And vice versa, a decrease of assets and an increase of liabilities account for a **source** of cash.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Sources of cash:}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Increase in accounts payable}&\$2,894 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Increase in common stock}&\$0 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Decrease in notes payable}&\$1,538 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Increase in retained earnings}&\underline{\$16,110} \\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Total sources}&\underline{\$20,542 } \\
\\
\text{Uses of cash:}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Increase in accounts receivable}&\$3,433 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Increase in inventory}&\$2,572 \\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Decrease in long-term debt}&-\$4,000\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Net fixed asset acquisitions}&\underline{\$8,589} \\
\hspace{20pt}\text{Total uses}&\underline{\$10,594 } \\
\\
\text{Net addition to cash} &\underline{\underline{\$1,948}} \\
\end{array}$$

We can see that in the case of Just Dew It corp, there is a 1:1 proportion between the Total Assets and Liabilities and Owners Equity in both years. This can only mean that the increments of assets during that period of time of one year were proportional. The only outstanding change we can observe is the decrease of long-term debt, however, this does not affect the overall financial health of the company since the short-term debt increased during this same period and compensates for this change, if anything this affects liquidity.
